Note that 𝒯2subscript𝒯2\mathcal{T}_{2} and 𝒪3subscript𝒪3\mathcal{O}_{3} and therefore 𝒜2subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{2} and its inverse are real with 𝒜m​(k+,k−)+=𝒜m​(k−,k+)−superscriptsubscript𝒜𝑚subscript𝑘subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒜𝑚subscript𝑘subscript𝑘\mathcal{A}_{m(k_{+},k_{-})}^{+}=\mathcal{A}_{m(k_{-},k_{+})}^{-}.

id_table_4.caption: New coefficients of third order of ℳ2subscriptℳ2\mathcal{M}_{2} after the second order transformation. Note that the first order terms remain unchanged and that the second order terms are all eliminated by the second order transformation. Interestingly, the second order transformation caused terms of the third order to disappear in this specific case, this is not a general property of the second order transformation. The component ℳ2+superscriptsubscriptℳ2\mathcal{M}_{2}^{+} is on the left, ℳ2−superscriptsubscriptℳ2\mathcal{M}_{2}^{-} on the right. The emphasized terms are surviving the third order transformation as explained in the following subsection.
